body: So far we're playing around with mapbox arc.js.
Loading and drawing paths is working.

However, the arc animation seems pretty buggy. I'm also not sold on it visually for our purposes. 

How easy would it be to sub in a simpler way of drawing connecting lines? Do we have other candidates that we could try?

Can we reduce the number of steps a user must take before submitting? Right now they have to type in an address, choose a geocoding result, click on that point, do the same process again, and then click submit.
No labels on hover for MVP.
This also begs the question if we should allow users to submit the exact same result for multiple point entries. (Maybe prompt for more specific address entries?)
We should either set a hard limit at 5 or inform the user that they can submit a max of five points. Probably should do both.

Another option for the email: we could have that submission send an email to a gmail account. 
https://pythonhosted.org/Flask-Mail/

That was intentional, we can change it, but that's how it's supposed to
work for now

On Fri, Oct 23, 2015, 9:49 PM Eric Sherman notifications@github.com wrote:

> entries just go sequentially into p1 and p2

Cool! I figured that was probably the case. I promise we'll nail down a
structure soon.

## 

Eric Sherman
224-402-0004
https://github.com/teralytics/Leaflet.D3SvgOverlay

https://github.com/IvanSanchez/Leaflet.Polyline.SnakeAnim

Super sweet, but dosent work on leaflet 0.7 :confused:
Or should we represent p1==p2 as a dot instead of a line?
Sounds good for now.
Would like to have these added as soon as possible.
I know our current structure expects at least two separate points columns, so we can modify this schema slight if needed.
How difficult/time-consuming would it be for us to create some variables that would allow us to 'swap out' one or two different ways of rendering the polylines?
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/192220/what-is-the-most-efficient-elegant-way-to-parse-a-flat-table-into-a-tree/192462#192462 If we want to get super fancy.
https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox.js/example/v1.0.0/line-marker/
What is the purpose of the session_id? Does it group points into a polyline? Or does it group points/polylines into a visitor to the website? We need one column to answer each question.

My original thought is that the session id would group the points, which would then be ordered by submit_timestamp. We could add another column with a categorical label for each generation (p1, p2, etc.) 

| id | the_geom | session_id | generation | submit_timestamp | mz_lable | lastedit_timestamp |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | POINT | a | live/p1 | 2015-10-25 12:21:13 | Africa | 2015-10-26 12:21:13 |
| 2 | POINT | a | grew_up/p2 | 2015-10-25 12:23:13 | Mexico | 2015-10-26 12:21:13 |
| 3 | POINT | a | parents/p3 | 2015-10-25 12:23:13 | Sicily | 2015-10-26 12:21:13 |
This is done, triggers added to the backend of the points table in cartodb.

![schema](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10539855/10858075/30c796fe-7f20-11e5-9f29-b28c6bb182a0.PNG)

Final schema for now unless there is a major problem. the_geom contains all the point geometries for that submission, the labels will have the location names for each, triggers will update the timestamps.
Great work!
Good enough for now.
Not sure if this is still needed or if we can come up with a better solution.
Markers should only appear below a certain zoom level, too cluttered at the world view.
Still working out this language. We also need a way to call out to the user that they are supposed to use the pelias dialog box to search....

After putting in two points, its very easy for the user to then click the submit button, since its right where the confirm button used to be. We need to make it easy to understand that they can/should submit up to 5 points before submitting.
Using polyline snake animation.
